title: 108_hr2061
content: The Act is titled the "National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Reauthorization Act of 2003" and includes general improvements to the National Anti-Drug Media Campaign. The Drug-Free Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act, focusing on preventing drug abuse among young people, increasing awareness of adults, and encouraging discussions about the dangers of drug use. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to focus on preventing drug abuse among young people. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug Free America, determines the overall purposes and strategy of the national media campaign, with responsibilities including implementing a focused national media campaign and approving advertising and purchase plans. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, is responsible for recommending strategies and creating advertising for the national media campaign to address drug threats at national, regional, and local levels. The Director shall enter into a contract with a media buying contractor to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the national media campaign, including testing all advertisements prior to use to ensure effectiveness and meeting industry standards. The Director will contract a media buying contractor to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the national media campaign, including strategic planning and accounting for purchases. The Director will allocate funds for the national media campaign to meet its goals, with an exception for creative development of advertisements unless targeting specific audiences that cannot be reached at no cost. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America is unable to provide such advertisements, and the Director must give prior notice to specific committees before making any changes. The national media campaign requires a no-cost match of equivalent value for advertising time and space or in-kind contributions related to substance abuse prevention. Advertising material donated at no cost must not be used for sponsorship identification. The national media campaign mandates that a minimum of 85% of funds be used for purchasing advertising time and space, with a cap of $5,000,000 for developing advertising material annually. SEC. 104 mandates financial and performance accountability. The Director is required to conduct audits and evaluations related to national media campaigns on drug abuse and submit a report to Congress. The Director conducts audits and evaluations on national media campaigns for drug abuse, tracking data according to industry standards, and submits a report to Congress as required. The Director submits an annual report to Congress detailing the national media campaign strategy, steps to ensure effectiveness, plans for advertising, responsible use of funds, and contracts. Additionally, $195,000,000 is authorized for the Office of National Drug Control Policy for fiscal years 2004 through 2008.
